tips: Include the whole script into a BEGIN; ... COMMIT; block
Begin the script with DROP SCHEMA IF EXISTS schema_name CASCADE;
Use a unique search_path for each dataset
Group insertions into a single INSERT INTO statement for each table to greatly improve performance

about.title: About LensQL
about.p1: LensQL is an interactive platform that helps students learn SQL through guided practice, personalized feedback, and gamified progression. Built with both students and teachers in mind, it supports a deeper understanding of relational databases by focusing on the reasoning behind queries ‚Äî not just their correctness.
about.p2: Instead of offering immediate solutions, LensQL encourages active exploration. The AI assistant, Lens, helps students reflect on their mistakes, refine their logic, and grow their skills with every attempt. Teachers, meanwhile, gain insight into how students learn, where they struggle, and how to support them effectively.
about.p3: Whether you're running your first query or refining complex joins, LensQL turns every error into an opportunity to learn.
about.moreIntro: LensQL is developed as part of ongoing research at the University of Genoa. If you're curious about the academic background or technical details, here are some publications that explore the ideas behind it:
about.paper1: Analyzing Common Student Errors in SQL Query Formulation to Enhance Learning Support
about.paper1Desc: A large-scale study on student SQL mistakes and how they vary across learning settings.
about.paper2: Enhancing SQL Learning through Generative AI and Student Error Analysis
about.paper2Desc: A framework for AI-assisted feedback, error tracking, and personalized assignment generation in SQL education.

hero.title: Learn SQL Through Mistakes ‚Äì With LensQL
hero.subtitle: Discover SQL. Learn from your errors. Grow with Lens.
hero.description: LensQL is an AI-powered SQL learning platform that turns student mistakes into personalized, interactive learning moments.

what_is.title: What is LensQL?
what_is.subtitle: A smarter way to learn SQL ‚Äî grounded in your mistakes, powered by AI.

features.ai_tutor: ü§ñ AI-driven tutor that helps students debug queries and think critically
features.error_pedagogy: üß† Error-based pedagogy: Learn from syntax, logic, and semantic mistakes
features.personalization: üéØ Personalized assignments and dashboards based on real progress

what_is.quote: ‚ÄúOver 95% of queries are submitted outside class hours. LensQL supports self-paced, reflective learning.‚Äù

how_it_works.title: How Does LensQL Work
steps: üßë‚Äçüè´ Teachers create exercises, optionally targeting known error types
üéì Students solve queries with Lens‚Äô help ‚Äî no direct answers, only interactive guidance
üìä The system analyzes every query to extract error patterns and track progress
üõ†Ô∏è Personalized exercises are automatically generated to address specific weaknesses
üìà Interactive learning dashboards show students and teachers how understanding evolves over time

meet_lens.title: Meet Lens: Your SQL Sidekick
meet_lens.description: Lens used to be an explorer of ancient data relics ‚Äî until a mysterious SQL query turned them into an AI. Now, Lens guides students through the twists and the joins of query logic with curiosity, kindness, and clear feedback.

features.describe_query: üß≠ Describes your query's behavior to help reflect on intent vs result
features.suggest_after_reflection: ‚ö†Ô∏è Gives suggestions only after reflection ‚Äî to foster genuine learning

students.title: For Students
items: üß† Understand the why, not just the how

gamification.title: üéÆ Gamified Learning That Rewards Effort and Insight
gamification.description: Learning SQL should feel rewarding ‚Äî and a little fun, too. LensQL uses two progression systems that motivate students to practice, reflect, and grow.

xp.title: üîπ XP and Levels ‚Äî Progress Through Practice
xp.description: Earn experience by writing and running queries. Leveling up shows your growth over time and rewards consistent effort ‚Äî not just correct answers.
xp.quote: ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to be perfect ‚Äî just consistent. The more you experiment, the more you grow.‚Äù

coins.title: ü™ô LensCoins ‚Äî Use Wisely, Reflect Deeply
coins.description: LensCoins are earned through engagement and spent when asking Lens for help. They encourage students to try before asking ‚Äî and to reflect on feedback.
coins.quote: ‚ÄúLensCoins encourage reflection. Spend them when you're truly stuck ‚Äî and earn them back by solving more and helping Lens improve.‚Äù

why.title: üí° Why It Works
items: ü§ù Builds a dialogue between students and the AI assistant
üîÑ Helps teachers see who‚Äôs trying, not just who‚Äôs succeeding

students.title: For Students
items: üìå Track how many queries you‚Äôve run and how often they work
üìä Understand what types of queries you write and how they change over time
ü§ñ See when and why you interact with Lens, and how you respond to its suggestions
üïí Follow your learning progress with a timeline of queries and errors

teachers.title: For Teachers
items: üìä View aggregate metrics for each dataset: query activity, success rate, and help usage
üìÇ Analyze errors by category: syntax, semantic, logical, or complications
üïí Track how query behavior and error patterns evolve over time
üß≠ Adapt instruction based on what students try, not just what they get right

demo.title: üöÄ Try LensQL Now
demo.description: While LensQL requires registration, here‚Äôs a sneak peek of how it helps you reason about errors step by step.
demo.example_caption: Example: SELECT name FROM students WHERE grade > AVG(grade)
demo.example_note: Lens identifies a syntax error and explains it in plain language, without giving the answer.

Simple Select.label: Simple SELECT
Simple Select.description: Write a simple SELECT statement to retrieve data from a single table.

Single condition.label: Single condition
Single condition.description: Write queries that filter results based on a single condition.

Distinct.label: DISTINCT
Distinct.description: Use the DISTINCT keyword to eliminate duplicate rows from query results.

Aggregate functions.label: Aggregate functions
Aggregate functions.description: Use aggregate functions like COUNT, SUM, AVG, MIN, and MAX to summarize data.

Subquery in SELECT.label: Subquery in SELECT
Subquery in SELECT.description: Write queries that include subqueries in the SELECT clause.

Case statements.label: CASE statements
Case statements.description: Use CASE statements to create conditional logic within queries.

String functions.label: String functions
String functions.description: Apply string functions to manipulate text data in queries.

Date functions.label: Date functions
Date functions.description: Use date functions to manipulate and format date and time data in queries.

Numeric functions.label: Numeric functions
Numeric functions.description: Apply numeric functions to perform calculations on numeric data in queries.

Window functions.label: Window functions
Window functions.description: Use window functions to perform calculations across a set of rows related to the current row.

Simple join.label: Simple JOIN
Simple join.description: Write queries that involve a simple join between two tables to retrieve related data.

Self join.label: Self JOIN
Self join.description: Write queries that involve self-joins to compare rows within the same table.

Left join.label: LEFT JOIN
Left join.description: Write queries that use LEFT JOIN to retrieve all rows from one table and matching rows from another.

Right join.label: RIGHT JOIN
Right join.description: Write queries that use RIGHT JOIN to retrieve all rows from one table and matching rows from another.

Full outer join.label: FULL OUTER JOIN
Full outer join.description: Use FULL OUTER JOIN to retrieve all rows when there is a match in either table.

Subquery in FROM.label: Subquery in FROM
Subquery in FROM.description: Utilize subqueries in the FROM clause to create derived tables.

Multiple conditions.label: Multiple conditions
Multiple conditions.description: Use logical operators to filter results based on multiple conditions.

Subquery in WHERE.label: Subquery in WHERE
Subquery in WHERE.description: Use subqueries in the WHERE clause to filter results based on related data.

Correlated subqueries.label: Correlated subqueries
Correlated subqueries.description: Write correlated subqueries that reference columns from the outer query.

Group by.label: GROUP BY
Group by.description: Group results using the GROUP BY clause to aggregate data based on specific columns.

Group by with conditions.label: HAVING clause
Group by with conditions.description: Use the HAVING clause to filter grouped results based on aggregate conditions.

Order by.label: ORDER BY
Order by.description: Sort query results using the ORDER BY clause.

Limit and offset.label: LIMIT and OFFSET
Limit and offset.description: Use LIMIT and OFFSET to control the number of rows returned by a query.

Union.label: UNION
Union.description: Combine results from multiple queries using the UNION operator.

Intersect.label: INTERSECT
Intersect.description: Retrieve common results from multiple queries using the INTERSECT operator.

Except.label: EXCEPT
Except.description: Use the EXCEPT operator to find results in one query that are not in another.

syn.name: Syntax Errors
syn.description: Incorrect SQL syntax, such as missing keywords, incorrect punctuation, or malformed statements.

sem.name: Semantic Errors
sem.description: Correct syntax but query is meaningless, such as always returning an empty result set.

log.name: Logical Errors
log.description: Query runs without errors but produces incorrect results due to flawed logic or misunderstanding of requirements.

com.name: Complications
com.description: Query returns the correct result but uses inefficient methods or complex constructs that could be simplified.

1.name: Omitting correlation names
1.description: When using multiple tables in a query, a column present in more than one table is referenced without specifying which table it belongs to.
1.explanation: Both tables contain a column named 'id'. Without specifying the table, the database cannot determine which 'id' to use.

2.name: Ambiguous column
2.description: When using multiple tables in a query, a column present in more than one table is referenced without specifying which table it belongs to.
2.explanation: Both tables contain a column named 'id'. Without specifying the table, the database cannot determine which 'id' to use.

3.name: Ambiguous function
3.description: Multiple functions with the same name exist, and the query does not specify which one to use.
3.explanation: There are two functions named 'my_function', one that takes an interval and another that takes a time. The query does not specify which function to use, leading to ambiguity.

4.name: Undefined column
4.description: The query references a column that does not exist in the specified table(s).
4.explanation: The table students does not contain a column named 'credit_card'.

5.name: Undefined function
5.description: The query references a function that does not exist or is not defined.
5.explanation: The function CAPSLOCK does not exist in the database.

6.name: Undefined parameter
6.description: The query references a parameter that does not exist or is not defined. Also, placeholder parameters are used incorrectly.
6.explanation: The query uses placeholder parameters instead of actual values. This is valid syntax in prepared statements, but not in regular queries.
6.correction: SELECT name FROM students WHERE id = 1;

7.name: Undefined object
7.description: The query references a table that does not exist or is not defined.
7.explanation: The table cats does not exist in the database.

8.name: Invalid schema name
8.description: The query references a schema that does not exist or is not defined.
8.explanation: The schema school does not exist in the database. In this example, the students table resides in the public schema.

9.name: Misspellings
9.description: The query contains misspelled table names, column names, or other identifiers.
9.explanation: The table studnets does not exist in the database. It is a misspelling of 'students'.

10.name: Synonyms
10.description: The query uses synonyms or alternative names for tables or columns that do not exist.
10.explanation: The table pupils does not exist in the database. It is a synonym for 'students', which is the correct table name.

11.name: Omitting quotes around character data
11.description: Character data values are not enclosed in quotes, which is required for string literals.
11.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE name = John;
11.explanation: Character data values must be enclosed in single quotes to be recognized as string literals.

12.name: Failure to specify column name twice
12.description: When using multiple conditions on the same column, the column name is not specified for each condition.
12.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age > 18 AND < 25;
12.explanation: Each condition in the WHERE clause must explicitly specify the column name it applies to.
12.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age > 18 AND age < 25;

13.name: Data type mismatch
13.description: The query uses incompatible data types in an operation or comparison.
13.explanation: The condition in the WHERE clause compares a string column (name) with an integer value (7), which is not valid.

14.name: Using aggregate function outside SELECT or HAVING
14.description: An aggregate function is used in a part of the query where it is not allowed, such as WHERE or GROUP BY.
14.explanation: Aggregate functions can only be used in the SELECT clause or the HAVING clause when grouping results. This query is attempting to use AVG in the WHERE clause, which is not allowed.
14.correction: SELECT * FROM students GROUP BY class HAVING AVG(score) > 80;

15.name: Grouping error: aggregate functions cannot be nested
15.description: Aggregate functions cannot be nested within each other in a query.
15.example: SELECT SUM(AVG(score)) FROM students GROUP BY class;
15.explanation: This query attempts to nest the AVG function inside the SUM function, which is not allowed. Instead, you can use a subquery to first calculate the average scores per group and then sum those averages.
15.correction: SELECT SUM(score) FROM (SELECT AVG(score) AS score FROM students GROUP BY class) AS avg_scores;

16.name: Grouping error: extraneous or omitted grouping column
16.description: When using GROUP BY, all non-aggregated columns in the SELECT clause must be included in the GROUP BY clause. Only aggregated columns or columns included in the GROUP BY clause can be referenced in the HAVING clause.
16.example: SELECT name, AVG(score) FROM students GROUP BY class;
16.explanation: The query selects the column 'name' which is neither aggregated nor included in the GROUP BY clause. This leads to ambiguity about which 'name' to return for each group. To fix this, either include 'name' in the GROUP BY clause or remove it from the SELECT clause.
16.correction: SELECT class, AVG(score) FROM students GROUP BY class;

17.name: Strange HAVING: HAVING without GROUP BY
17.description: The query uses a HAVING clause without a corresponding GROUP BY clause.
17.explanation: The HAVING clause is used to filter grouped results and should always be used in conjunction with a GROUP BY clause.
17.correction: SELECT class, AVG(score) FROM students GROUP BY class HAVING AVG(score) > 80;

18.name: Confusing function with function parameter
18.description: A function is confused with its parameter, leading to incorrect query syntax or logic.
18.explanation: The query incorrectly uses parentheses around the function name COUNT, which makes it look like a parameter rather than a function call. The correct syntax is to use COUNT without parentheses around it.

19.name: Using WHERE twice
19.description: The query contains multiple WHERE clauses, which is not allowed.
19.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age > 18 WHERE grade = 'A';
19.explanation: A query can only have one WHERE clause. Combine multiple conditions using logical operators like AND or OR.
19.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age > 18 AND grade = 'A';

20.name: Omitting the FROM clause
20.description: The query is missing the FROM clause and does not select a constant value.
20.explanation: The FROM clause is required in a SELECT statement to specify the table from which to retrieve data.
20.correction: SELECT name FROM students WHERE age > 18;

21.name: Comparison with NULL
21.description: The query uses a comparison with NULL using operators like = or != instead of IS NULL or IS NOT NULL.
21.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE name = NULL;
21.explanation: When checking for NULL values, use IS NULL or IS NOT NULL instead of standard comparison operators.
21.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE name IS NULL;

22.name: Omitting the semicolon
22.description: The query is missing the terminating semicolon at the end of the statement.
22.explanation: SQL standard requires each statement to end with a semicolon (;). Make sure to include it at the end of your queries.

23.name: Date time field overflow
23.description: An invalid date or time value is used in the query.
23.explanation: The date '2024-02-33' is invalid because a month cannot have 33 days. Ensure that date and time values are valid according to the calendar.

24.name: Duplicate clause
24.description: A clause is repeated in the query, such as multiple WHERE or ORDER BY clauses.
24.example: SELECT * FROM students ORDER BY age ORDER BY name;
24.explanation: This query is invalid because it contains two ORDER BY clauses. Each clause should only appear once in a query.
24.correction: SELECT * FROM students ORDER BY age, name;

25.name: Using an undefined correlation name
25.description: The query references a correlation name (alias) that has not been defined.
25.example: SELECT s2.name FROM students AS s;
25.explanation: This query renames the students table to 's' but then tries to reference it as 's2', which is not defined.
25.correction: SELECT s.name FROM students AS s;

26.name: Too many columns in subquery
26.description: A subquery returns more columns than expected in the context where it is used.
26.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE id IN (SELECT * FROM teachers);
26.explanation: The subquery in the WHERE clause is expected to return a single column of values to compare against the id column in the outer query. However, it returns all columns from the teachers table, leading to a mismatch.
26.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE id IN (SELECT id FROM teachers);

27.name: Confusing table names with column names
27.description: A table name is used where a column name is expected, or vice versa.
27.explanation: This query tries the access a column called 'students' from the 'name' table, which does not exist. The correct syntax is to specify the table name followed by the column name.

29.name: Projection in WHERE clause
29.description: Multiple columns are listed in the WHERE clause instead of a boolean expression.
29.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE firstname, surname;
29.explanation: This query incorrectly lists multiple columns in the WHERE clause, instead of a condition that evaluates to true or false. The WHERE clause should contain a boolean expression that filters the rows based on specified criteria.
29.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE firstname = 'John' AND surname = 'Doe';

30.name: Confusing the order of keywords
30.description: Keywords in the SQL statement are in the wrong order.
30.explanation: Ensure that SQL keywords are in the correct order: SELECT, FROM, WHERE, GROUP BY, HAVING, ORDER BY, LIMIT, OFFSET.

31.name: Confusing the logic of keywords
31.description: The wrong keyword is used for the intended operation, such as using GROUP BY instead of ORDER BY.
31.explanation: This query mixes up the SELECT and ORDER BY keywords. The correct syntax is to first SELECT the columns and then ORDER the results.
31.correction: SELECT name FROM students ORDER BY name;

32.name: Confusing the syntax of keywords
32.description: Each SQL keyword has a specific syntax that must be followed.
32.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age BETWEEN 18;
32.explanation: The BETWEEN operator requires two values to define the range: a lower bound and an upper bound.
32.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age BETWEEN 18 AND 25;

33.name: Omitting commas
33.description: When listing multiple columns or values, commas are missing between them.
33.example: SELECT firstname lastname age FROM students;
33.explanation: This query is missing commas between the column names in the SELECT clause. Ensure that each column name is separated by a comma.
33.correction: SELECT firstname, lastname, age FROM students;

34.name: Curly, square or unmatched brackets
34.description: Curly and square brackets are used instead of parentheses, or parentheses are unmatched.
34.explanation: Use only parentheses () for grouping expressions in SQL, and ensure that all opening parentheses have a corresponding closing parenthesis.

35.name: IS where not applicable
35.description: The IS operator is used for comparisons on values other than NULL or boolean expressions.
35.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age IS 18;
35.explanation: The IS operator should only be used for checking NULL values or boolean expressions (e.g., IS TRUE, IS FALSE). For other comparisons, use standard comparison operators like =, <>, >, <, >=, <=.

36.name: Nonstandard keywords or standard keywords in wrong context
36.description: The query uses invalid keywords or standard keywords in inappropriate contexts.
36.example: SELECT * FROM students SORT BY name;
36.explanation: The correct keyword for sorting results in SQL is ORDER BY, not SORT BY.
36.correction: SELECT * FROM students ORDER BY name;

37.name: Nonstandard operators
37.description: The query uses operators that are not part of the standard SQL syntax, such as &&, ||, or == instead of AND, OR, or =.
37.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age == 18 && grade == 'A';
37.explanation: Use standard SQL operators for logical and comparison operations: AND, OR, =, <>, >, <, >=, <=. Other operators, although common in programming languages, are not valid in SQL.
37.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age = 18 AND grade = 'A';

38.name: Additional semicolon
38.description: An extra semicolon is present in the query, which can lead to syntax errors.
38.explanation: Ensure that there is only one semicolon at the end of the SQL statement.

39.name: AND instead of OR (empty result table)
39.description: Query uses AND where OR is needed, resulting always in an empty result set.
39.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age < 18 AND age > 25;
39.explanation: The condition age < 18 AND age > 25 is attempting to find students who are both younger than 18 and older than 25 at the same time, which is impossible. Use OR to find students who meet either condition.
39.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age < 18 OR age > 25;

40.name: Implied, tautological or inconsistent expression
40.description: Query contains expressions that are always true, always false, or logically redundant.
40.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age > 10 AND age > 5 AND name = name;
40.explanation: The expression age > 10 AND age > 5 is redundant because if age is greater than 10, it is inherently greater than 5. Additionally, the condition name = name is always true for all rows. Simplifying the query to remove these redundancies will improve clarity and performance.

41.name: DISTINCT in SUM or AVG
41.description: Using DISTINCT within SUM or AVG means that only unique values are summed or averaged, which is almost never the intended behavior.
41.explanation: This query first considers all the unique students ages (each value is counted only once) and then calculates the average of those unique ages. If there are 200 students aged 20 and 1 student aged 30, the average will be (20 + 30) / 2 = 25, which does not accurately reflect the average age of all students.

42.name: DISTINCT that might remove important duplicates
42.description: Using DISTINCT removes duplicate rows from the result set, which may inadvertently exclude important data.
42.example: SELECT DISTINCT name from students WHERE grade = 'A';
42.explanation: If multiple students share the same name and have received an 'A' grade, using DISTINCT will return only one instance of that name, potentially omitting other students with the same name who also earned an 'A'. This could lead to incomplete or misleading results.
42.correction: SELECT name from students WHERE grade = 'A';

43.name: Wildcards without LIKE
43.description: Wildcards such as % or _ are used with = instead of LIKE, resulting in a literal comparison rather than a pattern match.
43.explanation: This query selects all students whose name is exactly 'J%n', including the percent sign, rather than matching names that start with 'J' and end with 'n' with any characters in between.
43.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE name LIKE 'J%n';

44.name: Incorrect wildcard: using _ instead of % or using, e.g., *
44.description: Wildcards are used incorrectly in pattern matching, such as using _ when % is needed, or using non-standard wildcards like *.
44.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE name LIKE 'J*n';
44.explanation: The query uses the non-standard wildcard * instead of the SQL standard wildcard %. The * character is not recognized by LIKE for pattern matching in SQL and is instead treated as a literal character.
44.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE name LIKE 'J%n';

45.name: Mixing a > 0 with IS NOT NULL or empty string with NULL
45.description: Using > 0 or = '' to check for non-null values instead of IS NOT NULL or IS NULL.
45.explanation: This query erroneously attempts to find students who haven't taken the test by checking for an empty string in the test_score column. However, this query actually selects students who have taken the test and have been assigned a score of '' (empty string).
45.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE test_score IS NULL;

46.name: NULL in IN/ANY/ALL subquery
46.description: Using nullable values in IN, ANY, or ALL subqueries can lead to unexpected results due to the way NULLs are handled in SQL.
46.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age IN (SELECT age FROM teachers);
46.explanation: This query attempts to find students who have the same age as any teacher. However, if the subquery returns any NULL values, the entire IN condition evaluates to UNKNOWN for those rows, which means they will not be included in the result set. This can lead to missing data if there are NULL ages in the teachers table.
46.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age IN (SELECT age FROM teachers WHERE age IS NOT NULL);

47.name: Join on incorrect column (matches impossible)
47.description: A join is performed on columns that cannot logically match, resulting in an empty result set.
47.example: SELECT * FROM students JOIN teachers ON students.age = teachers.salary;
47.explanation: This query attempts to join the students and teachers tables based on the condition that a student's age equals a teacher's salary. Since age and salary are fundamentally different types of data, this join condition is illogical and will likely result in no matching rows.
47.correction: SELECT * FROM students JOIN teachers ON students.class_id = teachers.class_id;

48.name: Omitting a join
48.description: A join condition is missing or incomplete, leading to a Cartesian product or incorrect results.
48.example: SELECT class.name, teacher.name FROM classes, teachers;
48.explanation: This query retrieves all combinations of classes and teachers without specifying how they are related. This results in a Cartesian product, where every class is paired with every teacher, which is not the intended outcome.
48.correction: SELECT class.name, teacher.name FROM classes, teachers WHERE classes.teacher_id = teachers.id;

49.name: Many duplicates
49.description: The query returns many times the same values, making the results difficult to interpret.
49.explanation: This query aims to find all the cities where students live. However, if multiple students live in the same city, that city will appear multiple times in the result set, leading to redundancy and making it harder to analyze the data.

50.name: Constant column output
50.description: A column in the output has the same constant value for all rows.
50.example: SELECT name, country WHERE country = 'IT' FROM students;
50.explanation: The country column does not provide any useful information because it has the same value ('IT') for all students in the result set. This redundancy can clutter the output and make it harder to focus on relevant data.
50.correction: SELECT name FROM students WHERE country = 'IT';

51.name: Duplicate column output
51.description: Multiple columns in the output always contain identical values.
51.example: SELECT first_name, last_name, first_name FROM students;
51.explanation: The query selects the first_name column twice, resulting in duplicate data in the output. This redundancy can confuse users and make it harder to interpret the results.

52.name: OR instead of AND
52.description: A condition uses OR where AND is needed, leading to broader results than intended.
52.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age > 18 OR grade = 'A';
52.explanation: This query is supposed to find students who are older than 18 and have received an 'A' grade. However, using OR means that it will return all students who are either older than 18 or have an 'A' grade.
52.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age > 18 AND grade = 'A';

53.name: Extraneous NOT operator
53.description: A condition uses NOT where it is not needed, leading to incorrect results.
53.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age > 18 AND NOT grade = 'A';
53.explanation: This query is intended to find students who are older than 18 and have received an 'A' grade. However, the NOT operator negates the grade condition, resulting in students who are older than 18 but have not received an 'A' grade.
53.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age > 18 AND grade = 'A';

54.name: Missing NOT operator
54.description: A condition is missing a NOT operator, leading to incorrect results.
54.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age > 18 AND grade = 'A';
54.explanation: This query is intended to find students who are older than 18 and have not received an 'A' grade. However, without the NOT operator, it returns students who have received an 'A' grade.
54.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age > 18 AND NOT grade = 'A';

55.name: Substituting existence negation with <>
55.description: The query uses <> to check for non-existence instead of NOT IN or NOT EXISTS.
55.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE id <> (SELECT student_id FROM graduates);
55.explanation: This query attempts to find students who are not graduates by using the <> operator. However, this query actually returns students whose id is not equal to the single value returned by the subquery, which is not the intended behavior. To correctly find students who are not graduates, use NOT IN or NOT EXISTS.
55.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE id NOT IN (SELECT student_id FROM graduates);

56.name: Putting NOT in front of incorrect IN/EXISTS
56.description: When multiple IN/EXISTS subqueries are used, NOT is applied to the wrong one, leading to incorrect results.
56.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE id NOT IN (SELECT student_id FROM graduates) AND id IN (SELECT student_id FROM enrolled);
56.explanation: This query is intended to find students who are enrolled but not graduates. However, the NOT operator is applied to the first IN subquery, which checks for graduates, instead of the second IN subquery, which checks for enrolled students. This results in incorrect filtering of the students.
56.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE id IN (SELECT student_id FROM enrolled) AND id NOT IN (SELECT student_id FROM graduates);

57.name: Incorrect comparison operator or incorrect value compared
57.description: A condition uses the wrong comparison operator or compares against an incorrect value, leading to unintended results.
57.explanation: This query is intended to find students who are 18 years old or older. However, the wrong age value is used in the comparison, resulting in only students who are 25 years old or older being returned.

58.name: Join on incorrect table
58.description: The query refences the wrong table, leading to incorrect or unexpected results.
58.explanation: This query is intended to retrieve the names of students, but it mistakenly references the teachers table instead of the students table.

59.name: Join when join needs to be omitted
59.description: The query references more tables than necessary, leading to incorrect or unexpected results.
59.example: SELECT name FROM students, teachers WHERE ...;
59.explanation: This query is intended to retrieve the names of students that meet certain criteria, but it unnecessarily joins the teachers table, which is not needed for this purpose. This can lead to incorrect results if there are multiple teachers associated with a student or if there are no matching teachers.

60.name: Join on incorrect column (matches possible)
60.description: A join condition uses the wrong column, leading to incorrect or unexpected results.
60.example: SELECT students.name FROM students JOIN teachers ON students.class_id = teachers.favourite_number;
60.explanation: This query is intended to retrieve the names of students who are associated with specific teachers. However, the join condition uses the favourite_number column from the teachers table, which is not logically related to the class_id column from the students table. This can lead to incorrect or unexpected results, as the join may match students with unrelated teachers based on arbitrary favourite numbers.
60.correction: SELECT students.name FROM students JOIN teachers ON students.class_id = teachers.class_id;

61.name: Join with incorrect comparison operator
61.description: A join condition uses the wrong comparison operator, leading to incorrect or unexpected results.
61.example: SELECT students.name FROM students JOIN teachers ON students.class_id > teachers.class_id;
61.explanation: This query is intended to retrieve the names of students who are associated with specific teachers. However, the join condition uses the > operator, which checks for a greater-than relationship between students.class_id and teachers.class_id. This is not the intended behavior, as the join should be based on equality to correctly associate students with their teachers.
61.correction: SELECT students.name FROM students JOIN teachers ON students.class_id = teachers.class_id;

62.name: Missing join
62.description: The query refences less tables than necessary, leading to incomplete results.
62.explanation: This query is intended to retrieve the names of students who are associated with specific teachers. However, it does not include a join with the teachers table, which is necessary to filter students based on their associated teachers. As a result, the query may return incomplete results or fail to apply the intended filtering criteria.
62.correction: SELECT students.name FROM students, teachers WHERE ...;

63.name: Improper nesting of expressions
63.description: Expressions are not properly nested with parentheses, leading to incorrect evaluation order.
63.explanation: This query is intended to find students whose age plus 5, multiplied by 2, is greater than 30. However, without proper parentheses, the multiplication operator (*) has a higher precedence than addition (+), leading to an incorrect evaluation order.

64.name: Improper nesting of subqueries
64.description: Subqueries are nested improperly, leading to a different evaluation order than intended.
64.example: SELECT * FROM students s WHERE id NOT EXISTS (SELECT * FROM graduates g WHERE g.student_id = s.id AND EXISTS (SELECT * FROM tutors t WHERE t.student_id = s.id));
64.explanation: This query is intended to find students who are not graduates and have tutors. However, the nesting of the EXISTS subquery within the NOT EXISTS subquery returns students who are not graduates or have tutors, but not both.
64.correction: SELECT * FROM students s WHERE NOT EXISTS (SELECT * FROM graduates g WHERE g.student_id = s.id) AND EXISTS (SELECT * FROM tutors t WHERE t.student_id = s.id);

65.name: Extraneous quotes
65.description: A column name is enclosed in quotes, effectively turning it into a string literal.
65.explanation: This query is intended to find students who have the same name as their supervisor. However, by enclosing supervisor_name in quotes, it returns students whose name is literally 'supervisor_name', rather than comparing it to the value in the supervisor_name column.
65.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE name = supervisor_name;

70.name: Extraneous column in SELECT
70.description: A column is included in the SELECT clause that is not expected or needed for the intended result.
70.example: SELECT name, age, address FROM students;
70.explanation: The exercise requires only the names and ages of students, but the query also includes the address column in the SELECT clause. This adds unnecessary data to the result set.

71.name: Missing column from SELECT
71.description: A required column is missing from the SELECT clause.
71.explanation: The exercise requires both the names and ages of students, but the query only selects the name column, omitting the age column.

72.name: Missing DISTINCT from SELECT
72.description: A DISTINCT keyword is missing from the SELECT clause, leading to duplicate rows in the result set where uniqueness is required by the exercise.
72.explanation: The exercise requires a list of unique cities where students live. However, the query does not include the DISTINCT keyword, resulting in duplicate city names in the output.

73.name: Missing AS from SELECT
73.description: A column presents a different name from what is required by the exercise, due to the absence of an AS alias.
73.explanation: The exercise requires the output column to be labeled as 'student_name', but the query does not use an AS alias to rename the column.
73.correction: SELECT name AS student_name FROM students;

74.name: Missing column from ORDER BY clause
74.description: A required column is missing from the ORDER BY clause.
74.example: SELECT name, age FROM students ORDER BY name;
74.explanation: The exercise requires the results to be ordered by both name and age. However, the query only orders the results by name, omitting age from the ORDER BY clause.
74.correction: SELECT name, age FROM students ORDER BY name, age;

75.name: Incorrect column in ORDER BY clause
75.description: An incorrect column is used in the ORDER BY clause, leading to results being sorted in an unintended manner.
75.example: SELECT name, age FROM students ORDER BY city;
75.explanation: The exercise requires the results to be ordered by name, but the query incorrectly orders the results by city instead.
75.correction: SELECT name, age FROM students ORDER BY name;

76.name: Extraneous ORDER BY clause
76.description: An ORDER BY clause is included in the query when the exercise does not require any specific ordering of the results.
76.example: SELECT name, age FROM students ORDER BY name;
76.explanation: The exercise does not specify any ordering for the results, so including an ORDER BY clause is unnecessary and adds complexity to the query.

77.name: Incorrect ordering of rows
77.description: The ORDER BY clause sorts the results in the wrong order (ascending instead of descending, or vice versa).
77.example: SELECT name, age FROM students ORDER BY age ASC;
77.explanation: The exercise requires the results to be ordered by age in descending order, but the query sorts the results in ascending order instead.
77.correction: SELECT name, age FROM students ORDER BY age DESC;

78.name: DISTINCT as function parameter where not applicable
78.description: DISTINCT is used within a function where it is not appropriate or necessary.
78.explanation: The exercise expects the total number of students who have a supervisor assigned, but the DISTICT keyword causes the COUNT function to count only unique supervisors, which is not the intended behavior.

79.name: Missing DISTINCT from function parameter
79.description: DISTINCT is missing within a function where it is required to ensure unique values are considered.
79.explanation: The exercise requires counting the number of supervisors assigned to students, counting each supervisor only once, regardless of how many students they supervise. However, the query counts all supervisor entries, including duplicates.

80.name: Incorrect function
80.description: An incorrect function is used for the intended operation, leading to unexpected results.
80.explanation: The exercise requires calculating the average age of students, but the query uses the SUM function instead of AVG, resulting in the total age rather than the average.

81.name: Incorrect column as function parameter
81.description: An incorrect column is used as a parameter for a function, leading to unintended results.
81.example: SELECT EXTRACT(month FROM birthdate) FROM students;
81.explanation: The exercise asks for the month the students graduated, but the query extracts the month of their birthdate instead.
81.correction: SELECT EXTRACT(month FROM graduation_date) FROM students;

82.name: Unnecessary complication
82.description: The query is more complex than necessary to achieve the intended result.
82.example: SELECT name FROM students WHERE age > 36 / 2 OR age = 9 * (12 - 2);
82.explanation: The exercise requires selecting students at least 18 years old. However, the query uses unnecessary arithmetic operations to express the age condition, making it more complicated than needed.
82.correction: SELECT name FROM students WHERE age >= 18;

83.name: Unnecessary DISTINCT in SELECT clause
83.description: DISTINCT is used on a SELECT clause where duplicate values cannot occur, adding unnecessary complexity.
83.example: SELECT DISTINCT id, name FROM students;
83.explanation: The id column is a primary key, meaning each value is unique. Therefore, using DISTINCT is redundant since there cannot be any duplicate rows in the result set based on the id column.

84.name: Unnecessary join
84.description: A table is joined just to access a value which is already available as a foreign key.
84.example: SELECT s.id, t.id FROM students s JOIN teachers t ON s.supervisor_id = t.id;
84.explanation: The exercise requires selecting the student IDs along with their supervisor IDs. However, the query unnecessarily joins the teachers table to retrieve the supervisor IDs, which are already available in the students table as foreign keys.

85.name: Unused correlation name
85.description: A correlation name (alias) is defined for a table but not used in the query.
85.explanation: The query defines a correlation name 's' for the students table but does not use it anywhere in the query. This adds unnecessary complexity without any benefit.

86.name: Correlation names are always identical
86.description: The query references two tables that always contain the same data.
86.example: SELECT a.name, b.name FROM students a JOIN students b ON a.id = b.id;
86.explanation: The query joins the students table with itself on the id column, which is a primary key. Since each id is unique, the join will always pair each student with themselves, resulting in identical data from both tables. This redundancy adds unnecessary complexity without any benefit.

86bis.name: Redundant correlation name
86bis.description: The query defines a correlation name (alias) for a table that is the same as the original table name, making the alias redundant.
86bis.example: SELECT students.name FROM students AS students students;
86bis.explanation: The query defines a correlation name 'students' for the students table, which is identical to the original table name. This redundancy adds unnecessary complexity without any benefit.

87.name: Unnecessarily general comparison operator
87.description: An operator used for a comparison can be replaced by a more specific one without changing the logic.
87.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age >= (SELECT MAX(age) FROM students);
87.explanation: The query is intended to find the oldest students. However, the ">" part of the operator is unnecessary because no student can be older than the maximum age. Using the more specific "=" operator makes the query clearer and more efficient.
87.correction: SELECT * FROM students WHERE age = (SELECT MAX(age) FROM students);

88.name: LIKE without wildcards
88.description: The LIKE operator is used without any wildcard characters, making it equivalent to a simple equality comparison.
88.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE name LIKE 'John';
88.explanation: The query uses the LIKE operator to compare the name column to 'John' without any wildcard characters. This makes the LIKE operator unnecessary, as it behaves the same way as the = operator in this case.

89.name: Unnecessarily complicated SELECT in EXISTS subquery
89.description: The SELECT clause in an EXISTS subquery returns more than a single column, which is unnecessary since EXISTS only checks for the existence of rows.
89.example: SELECT name FROM students s WHERE EXISTS (SELECT id, name FROM teachers t WHERE t.name = s.name);
89.explanation: The EXISTS subquery is intended to find students who have the same name as any teacher. However, the SELECT clause in the subquery returns both id and name columns, which is unnecessary because EXISTS only checks for the existence of rows that meet the condition. Returning multiple columns adds unnecessary complexity without any benefit.
89.correction: SELECT name FROM students s WHERE EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM teachers t WHERE t.name = s.name);

90.name: IN/EXISTS can be replaced by comparison
90.description: A subuery using IN or EXISTS can be simplified to a direct comparison.
90.example: SELECT * FROM students WHERE id NOT IN (SELECT id FROM students WHERE age < 18);
90.explanation: The query finds students who are 18 years old or older by selecting those whose IDs are not in the set of IDs of students younger than 18. This can be simplified by checking the age directly, which is more straightforward and efficient.

91.name: Unnecessary aggregate function
91.description: An aggregate function is used on a single value.
91.example: SELECT MAX(age) FROM students WHERE id = 123;
91.explanation: The query retrieves the age of a specific student with id 123. Since the WHERE clause filters the results to a single row, using the MAX aggregate function is unnecessary, as there is only one value to return.
91.correction: SELECT age FROM students WHERE id = 123;

92.name: Unnecessary DISTINCT in aggregate function
92.description: DISTINCT is used within an aggregate function where all values are already unique, making it redundant.
92.explanation: The id column is a primary key, meaning each value is unique. Therefore, using DISTINCT within the COUNT function doesn't change the result, as there cannot be any duplicate ids to count.

93.name: Unnecessary argument of COUNT
93.description: COUNT is used with a specific column name instead of using COUNT(*) or COUNT(1) when counting non-nullable columns.
93.explanation: The name column is defined as NOT NULL, meaning it cannot contain any NULL values. Therefore, using COUNT(name) is equivalent to COUNT(*), as all rows will be counted. Using COUNT(*) is more straightforward and efficient in this case.

94.name: Unnecessary GROUP BY in EXISTS subquery
94.description: A GROUP BY clause is used in an EXISTS subquery where it is not needed, as EXISTS only checks for the existence of rows.
94.example: SELECT name FROM students s WHERE EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM teachers t GROUP BY t.name HAVING t.name = s.name);
94.explanation: The EXISTS subquery is intended to find students who have the same name as any teacher. However, the GROUP BY clause is unnecessary because EXISTS only checks for the existence of rows that meet the condition. Using GROUP BY adds unnecessary complexity without any benefit.
94.correction: SELECT name FROM students s WHERE EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM teachers t WHERE t.name = s.name);

95.name: GROUP BY with singleton groups
95.description: GROUP BY is used on groups that each contain only a single row, making the grouping unnecessary.
95.example: SELECT id, AVG(age) FROM students GROUP BY id;
95.explanation: The query groups the students by their id, which is a primary key. Since each id is unique, each group will contain only a single row. Therefore, using GROUP BY is unnecessary, as it does not change the result set.

96.name: GROUP BY with only a single group
96.description: GROUP BY is used in a way that results in only a single group, making the grouping unnecessary.
96.example: SELECT AVG(age) FROM students WHERE country = 'IT' GROUP BY country;
96.explanation: The query groups the students by country after filtering for those in 'IT'. Since all remaining rows belong to the same country, there is only a single group. Therefore, using GROUP BY is unnecessary, as it does not change the result set.
96.correction: SELECT AVG(age) FROM students WHERE country = 'IT';

97.name: GROUP BY can be replaced with DISTINCT
97.description: All GROUP BY columns are also in the SELECT clause without any aggregate functions, making DISTINCT a simpler alternative.
97.example: SELECT name, age FROM students GROUP BY name, age;
97.explanation: The query groups the students by their name and age, but does not use any aggregate functions. Since the SELECT clause only includes the grouped columns, using DISTINCT is a simpler and more efficient way to achieve the same result.
97.correction: SELECT DISTINCT name, age FROM students;

98.name: UNION can be replaced by OR
98.description: Two SELECT statements combined with UNION can be simplified to a single SELECT with an OR condition.
98.example: SELECT name FROM students WHERE age < 18 UNION SELECT name FROM students WHERE grade = 'A';
98.explanation: The query retrieves the names of students who are either younger than 18 or have received an 'A' grade. This can be simplified by using a single SELECT statement with an OR condition in the WHERE clause, which is more straightforward and efficient.
98.correction: SELECT name FROM students WHERE age < 18 OR grade = 'A';

99.name: Unnecessary column in ORDER BY clause
99.description: A column is included in the ORDER BY clause that does not affect the ordering of the results due to functional dependencies.
99.example: SELECT id, name FROM students ORDER BY id, name;
99.explanation: The query orders the results by both id and name. However, since id is a primary key, it uniquely identifies each row. Therefore, ordering by name after id does not change the order of the results, making it unnecessary.
99.correction: SELECT id, name FROM students ORDER BY id;

100.name: ORDER BY in subquery
100.description: An ORDER BY clause is used in a subquery where it does not affect the final result set.
100.example: SELECT name FROM students WHERE name IN (SELECT name FROM teachers ORDER BY name);
100.explanation: The query retrieves the names of students who have the same name as any teacher. However, the ORDER BY clause in the subquery is unnecessary, as the order of rows in a subquery does not impact the final result set of the outer query.
100.correction: SELECT name FROM students WHERE name IN (SELECT name FROM teachers);

101.name: Inefficient HAVING
101.description: A condition in the HAVING clause does not depend on aggregate functions and can be moved to the WHERE clause.
101.example: SELECT supervisor, COUNT(*) FROM students GROUP BY supervisor HAVING supervisor IS NOT NULL;
101.explanation: The HAVING clause is used to filter groups based on aggregate conditions. However, the condition 'supervisor IS NOT NULL' does not depend on any aggregate functions and can be applied before grouping. Moving this condition to the WHERE clause improves query efficiency by reducing the number of rows that need to be grouped.
101.correction: SELECT supervisor, COUNT(*) FROM students WHERE supervisor IS NOT NULL GROUP BY supervisor;

102.name: Inefficient UNION
102.description: A UNION operation can be replaced by UNION ALL without changing the result set, improving performance.
102.example: SELECT name FROM students WHERE age < 18 UNION SELECT name FROM students WHERE age > 30;
102.explanation: The two queries retrieve names of students from disjoint age groups (younger than 18 and older than 30). Since there is no overlap between these two groups, using UNION ALL is more efficient as it does not perform the additional step of removing duplicates, which is unnecessary in this case.
102.correction: SELECT name FROM students WHERE age < 18 UNION ALL SELECT name FROM students WHERE age > 30;

103.name: Condition in the subquery can be moved up
103.description: A condition in the subquery refences only values from the outer query and can be moved to the outer WHERE clause.
103.example: SELECT name FROM students s WHERE EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM teachers t WHERE t.name = s.name AND s.age > 18);
103.explanation: The condition 's.age > 18' in the subquery only references the outer query's table 'students'. Therefore, it can be moved to the outer WHERE clause, which can improve query readability and potentially performance.
103.correction: SELECT name FROM students s WHERE s.age > 18 AND EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM teachers t WHERE t.name = s.name);

104.name: Condition on left table in LEFT OUTER JOIN
104.description: Using a JOIN ON condition on the left table of a LEFT OUTER JOIN affects only the right table, which can lead to unexpected results.
104.example: SELECT s.name, t.name FROM students s LEFT OUTER JOIN teachers t ON s.supervisor_id = t.id AND s.age > 18;
104.explanation: The condition 's.age > 18' is applied only on the right table. If a student is younger than 18, the join will still include that student with NULL values for the teacher columns, which is not the internted behavior. To filter students based on age, the condition should be placed in the WHERE clause instead.
104.correction: SELECT s.name, t.name FROM students s LEFT OUTER JOIN teachers t ON s.supervisor_id = t.id WHERE s.age > 18;

105.name: OUTER JOIN can be replaced by INNER JOIN
105.description: Using a WHERE condition on the right table of a LEFT OUTER JOIN effectively turns it into an INNER JOIN.
105.example: SELECT s.name, t.name FROM students s LEFT OUTER JOIN teachers t ON s.supervisor_id = t.id WHERE t.department = 'Math';
105.explanation: The WHERE condition 't.department = 'Math'' filters out any rows where there is no matching teacher, which negates the purpose of the LEFT OUTER JOIN. In this case, an INNER JOIN is more appropriate and efficient.
105.correction: SELECT s.name, t.name FROM students s INNER JOIN teachers t ON s.supervisor_id = t.id WHERE t.department = 'Math';
